title: Penetrável PN1
transcript:
JAMES RONDEAU: The Penetrable is one of the great innovations of the first half of Helio’s career, we’re in 1960 and we’re really at a halfway point here in this really important narrative arc. From taking color, geometry and surface from the wall into three-dimensional space.

NARRATOR: For Oiticica, the Penetrable, also called PN-1, with it’s vibrant colors and sliding doors, was where the larger ideas of geometry, interactivity and - most importantly in this example - color, left the world of the visual and became manifested physically.

JAMES RONDEAU: What’s maybe most important here about PN-1 is not so much the idea of participation, which we can trace almost everywhere in Helio’s work, but here the idea of color, and the idea of immersion in color.

So these yellows and oranges that you have here, they’re intended not just to be colors on the wall, they’re intended to do at least two things: they’re intended to be color in motion as those plane’s slide; they’re intended then to be color that contains the body totally. So this is not being in a room with an orange or yellow wall, this is being in orange, this is being with yellow. He’s thinking even from 1960 about color in a very, very poetic, complicated and fully bodily way.
